Phyllonycteris aphylla.wikipediaNotes: Colonies only at Marta Tick Cave and Stony Hill Cave.[7]

Cystophora cristata.wikipediaNotes: One population in the Northwest Atlantic and another in the Northeast. The latter population has declined 85-90% in the past 60 years for unknown reasons.[69]

Pipile pipile.wikipediaNotes: Population is likely toward the top of this band.[2]

Pterodroma externa.wikipediaNotes: Minimum estimate from 1986, but population appears to remain steady.[94]

Nomascus hainanus.wikipediaNotes: Population was estimated at over 2,000 in the late 1950s.[1]

Procellaria aequinoctialis.wikipediaNotes: Estimate is for mature individuals only.[95]

Gorilla beringei.wikipediaNotes: Approximately 5,000 eastern lowland gorillas (G. b. graueri)[40] and 880 mountain gorillas (G. b. beringei).[41]

Ovis dalli.wikipediaNotes: Consists of approximately 41500 sheep in Canada and between 70000 and 75000 animals in the United States.[79]

Propithecus perrieri.wikipediaNotes: One of the 25 most endangered primates.[5]

Phoebastria nigripes.wikipediaNotes: Estimate is for mature individuals only.[58]

Anas aucklandica.wikipediaNotes: Estimate is for mature individuals only.[20]

Ovibos moschatus.wikipediaNotes: Estimate includes 75400 animals in the Northwest Territories, 45300 in Nunavut, 3714 in Alaska, and between 9500 and 12500 in Greenland.[84]

Natalus jamaicensis.wikipediaNotes: Only found in the St. Clair Cave in Jamaica. Population estimate was done in 1970.[3]

Oryx leucoryx.wikipediaNotes: 6000–7000 in captivity and c. 1000 in the wild.[35]

Pseudoryx nghetinhensis.wikipediaNotes: Maximum estimate. No individuals in captivity. Wild population highly dispersed, and subpopulations fragmented with numbers of mature individuals below the minimum viable population. Foremost threatened by hunting.[1]

Gyps tenuirostris.wikipediaNotes: "Likely" estimate; difficulties in quantifying have arisen due to taxonomic confusion.[67]

Equus africanus.wikipediaNotes: Maximum estimate. A small population may still exist in Somalia.[5]

Acinonyx jubatus.wikipediaNotes: Estimate is for mature individuals only. Number may reach as high as 10,000.[24]

Phoenicopterus roseus.wikipediaNotes: Divided into three separate populations: The Palearctic, stretching from West Africa to Kazakhstan (205 000 – 320 000); The South West and South Asian (240 000); and the sub-Saharan African (100 000 – 120 000).[4]

Antilocapra americana.wikipediaNotes: Numbered over 35000000 in the early 1800s and as little as 20000 in the early 1920s.[110]

Gazella leptoceros.wikipediaNotes: Estimate is for mature individuals only.[21]

Sarcogyps calvus.wikipediaNotes: Population undergoing collapse due to the use of diclofenac.[86]

Mergus squamatus.wikipediaNotes: Estimate is rough; further research needed.[30]

Balearica regulorum.wikipediaNotes: Numbers are from 2004; considered too high due to the rapidly decreasing population.[72]

Gyps indicus.wikipediaNotes: 97% population collapse since the mid-1990s, caused by diclofenac.[94]

Macaca munzala.wikipediaNotes: While one source gives a minimum estimate of 569, another claims adult species number less than 250.[15]

Eudyptes moseleyi.wikipediaNotes: Only mature individuals were included in the count (265 thousand pairs); population has declined 57% in the past 37 years.[17]

Cephalophus jentinki.wikipediaNotes: Maximum estimate; may be less than 2000.[27]

Columba argentina.wikipediaNotes: Preliminary maximum estimate; may be revised upwards.[2]

Aceros narcondami.wikipediaNotes: Only found on the 3 km×4 km Narcondam Island.[3]

Zenaida graysoni.wikipediaNotes: Not recorded in the wild since 1972. Re-introductions are planned.[8]

Tragelaphus buxtoni.wikipediaNotes: 2500 is a maximum estimate from 1999, but recent work has shown numbers may be as high as 4000.[23]

Oryx beisa.wikipediaNotes: Divided into two subspecies: Beisa (50000) and Fringe-eared (17000).[69]

Mesoplodon hotaula P. E. P. Deraniyagala.binomialName: Mesoplodon hotaula P. E. P. Deraniyagala, 1963

Cebus flavius.wikipediaNotes: Estimate is for mature individuals only.[3]

Himantopus knudnesi.wikipediaNotes: May be subspecies of black-necked stilt or black-winged stilt.

Lewinia muelleri.wikipediaNotes: Estimate is for mature population only.[34]

Trachypithecus johnii.wikipediaNotes: Maximum estimate; mature individuals number less than 10,000.[55]

Redunca fulvorufula.wikipediaNotes: Minimum estimate, divided into three subspecies: Southern (33000), Chanler's (2900), and Western (450).[62]

Penelopides panini.wikipediaNotes: Minimum estimate from 2001; considered possibly out of date.[10]

Natalus primus.wikipediaNotes: Maximum estimate. Only found in a single cave.[4]

Trachypithecus geei.wikipediaNotes: Maximum estimate; mature individuals number less than 2,500.[39]

Lynx pardinus.wikipediaNotes: According to European Union LIFE Nature conservation projects estimates population size tripled from 52 mature individuals in 2002 to 156 in 2012.[8]

Ursus arctos.wikipediaNotes: Minimum estimate. Russia has the largest number of brown bears, believed to exceed 100,000, while estimates in the U.S. are around 33,000 (most in Alaska), Canada 25,000, and Europe (excluding Russia) 14,000.[59]

Propithecus candidus.wikipediaNotes: Estimate is believed to be a maximum.[6]

Mirounga leonina.wikipediaNotes: Latest global estimates are from the mid-1990s.[68]

Gallirallus australis.wikipediaNotes: Divided into four subspecies: G. a. australis (50 000 – 100 000), G. a. greyi (~11 000), G. a. hectori (38 000 – 58 000), & G. a. scotti (<8000)[78]

Rhinopithecus bieti.wikipediaNotes: Maximum estimate; less than 1,000 mature organisms.[30]

Ara glaucogularis.wikipediaNotes: Estimate does not include captive individuals.[9]

Calyptorhynchus lathami.wikipediaNotes: Divided into three subspecies: C. L. lathami (1200), C. l. halmaturinus (140), & C. l. erebus (5000).[104]

Kobus ellipsiprymnus.wikipediaNotes: About 95000 of the Defassa subspecies and 105000 of the Common.[90]

Ursus americanus.wikipediaNotes: Numbers are believed to be twice that of all other bears combined.[71]

Procyon pygmaeus.wikipediaNotes: Mature individuals number less than 250. Populations can be severely affected by hurricanes.[7]

Cyanopsitta spixii.wikipediaNotes: Maximum estimate; possibly extinct in the wild.[4]

Mergus octosetaceus.wikipediaNotes: Estimate is for mature individuals only; numbers may be higher.[14]

Geophaps smithii.wikipediaNotes: Numbers are for mature individuals only. Divided into two subspecies: G. smithii smithi (120,000) & G. smithii blaauwi (6000).[80]

Pygoscelis adeliae.wikipediaNotes: Only mature individuals were included in the count (2.37 million pairs).[23]

Pteropus voeltzkowi.wikipediaNotes: Increase from a few hundred in the early 1990s.[26]

Nomascus nasutus.wikipediaNotes: Previously thought to be possibly extinct. Numbers may be higher.[2]

Catagonus wagneri.wikipediaNotes: Estimate was made in 2002; wide-scale deforestation of their habitat began in 2003.[25]

Hippopotamus amphibius.wikipediaNotes: Population was estimated to be between 125000 and 148000 in a 2008 assessment.[80]

Myotis sodalis.wikipediaNotes: Though numbers are large compared to other bats classified as endangered, this species is listed as such due to a >50% decline over the past decade.[31]

Eudyptes pachyrhynchus.wikipediaNotes: Only mature individuals were included in the count.[12]

Axis kuhlii.wikipediaNotes: Estimates are for the wild population only; may reach as high as 500.[3]

Sylvicapra grimmia.wikipediaNotes: Considered extremely conservative; yet-to-be-published research shows it may number as high as 10000000.[119]

Kobus leche.wikipediaNotes: Combined numbers of three subspecies: Red (98000), Kafue (78000), and Black (36000).[91]

Neochen jubata.wikipediaNotes: Estimate is for mature individuals only.[30]

Pterodroma cookii.wikipediaNotes: Estimate is for mature individuals only.[80]

Mesoplodon perrini Dalebout, Mead, Baker.binomialName: Mesoplodon perrini Dalebout, Mead, Baker, Baker, & van Helding, 2002

Gyps bengalensis.wikipediaNotes: Described in 1985 as "possibly the most abundant large bird of prey in the world", numbering millions. Catastrophic population collapse beginning in the 1990s has been caused by diclofenac, a drug used to treat livestock; after eating decaying bodies containing this substance, the vultures succumb to kidney failure. The only country with possible increases is Cambodia, where the drug is apparently unavailable.[90]

Equus ferus przewalskii.wikipediaNotes: Wild numbers only. Previously extinct in the wild.[4]

Pygoscelis papua.wikipediaNotes: Only mature individuals were included in the count (387 thousand pairs).[19]

Anodorhynchus glaucus.wikipediaNotes: Maximum estimate. Updated from "Extinct" in 2000 due to persistent unverified reports of its existence.[1]

Cephalophus zebra.wikipediaNotes: Could be overestimated; may be less than 15000.[55]

Polytelis anthopeplus.wikipediaNotes: Divided into two subspecies: P. a. anthopeplusis (20 000) & P. a. monarchoides (1500).[114]

Spheniscus magellanicus.wikipediaNotes: Only mature individuals were included in the count (1.3 million pairs).[22]

Saiga tatarica.wikipediaNotes: Numbers stood at 1250000 in the mid-1970s.[67]

Choeropsis liberiensis.wikipediaNotes: Estimate is from 1993; numbers have probably shrunk.[19]

Acerodon jubatus.wikipediaNotes: Rough estimate; probably no more than 20 000.[24]

Capra falconeri.wikipediaNotes: Estimate includes approximately 900 animals assumed to live in areas for which data is unavailable.[38]

Inia araguaiaensis Hrbek, Da Silva, Dutr.binomialName: Inia araguaiaensis Hrbek, Da Silva, Dutra, Farias, 2014

Prionailurus bengalensis iriomotensis.wikipediaNotes: A subspecies of the leopard cat living exclusively on the Japanese island of Iriomote. Population size is declining, and consists of a single subpopulation.[1]

Thalassarche chlororhynchos.wikipediaNotes: Estimate is for mature individuals only.[36]

Anas albogularis.wikipediaNotes: Estimate is for mature individuals only; numbers may be higher.[17]

Pteropus poliocephalus.wikipediaNotes: Estimates are based on incomplete knowledge of camp location and use.[29]

Anas eatoni.wikipediaNotes: Has not been estimated since the 1980s; numbers have probably declined.[49]

Panthera leo.wikipediaNotes: Comprises two subspecies in Africa and Asia. The Asiatic lion numbers an estimated 650.[44]

Phaenicophaeus pyrrhocephalus.wikipediaNotes: Recent study suggests much lower numbers.[7]

Spheniscus demersus.wikipediaNotes: 5000 breeding pairs in Namibia & 21 000 in South Africa.[14]

Eudyptes chrysolophus.wikipediaNotes: Only mature individuals were included in the count (9 million pairs); main population centres at Île des Pingouins, Heard and McDonald (1 million pairs each), Kerguelen (1.8 million pairs), & South Georgia (2.5 million pairs).[25]

Neotis ludwigii.wikipediaNotes: Population may be lower due to an apparent recent spate of power-line collisions.[74]

Pipistrellus murrayi.wikipediaNotes: Common and widespread until the 1980s. In January 2009, there were 4 individuals left. An immediate capturing project was requested to save the species, and efforts for approval included a personal meeting with then-Australian environment minister Peter Garrett. Due to a potential cost of a few hundred thousand dollars, the government decided against quick action and instead undertook a bureaucratic feasibility study. After its eventual assent in August 2009 a team of experts travelled to Christmas Island to capture the remaining individuals but only one was detected, which managed not to be caught. On August 27, 2009, the last remaining individual disappeared, causing the species to become extinct. Its subsequent disappearance may be one of very few times extinction has been witnessed first-hand. Reasons for the bat's extinction remain unknown.[1][2]

Homo sapiens.wikipediaNotes: Population is rapidly increasing and is the main cause for dwindling non-human primate populations as well as most other species.

Capra pyrenaica.wikipediaNotes: Numbered only c. 7900 in the early 1990s.[66]

Phoebetria fusca.wikipediaNotes: Estimate is for mature individuals only (14 000 pairs).[39]

Apus apus.wikipediaNotes: Preliminary estimate extrapolated from European data.[86]

Eumetopias jubatus.wikipediaNotes: Divided into two subspecies: Western Steller (78,000) and Loughlin's Steller (65,000).[56]

Viverra civettina.wikipediaNotes: Maximum estimate. Previously considered possibly extinct.[3]

Oceanodroma monorhis.wikipediaNotes: Quite possibly underestimated; a recent study gives a minimum of 130 000 pairs.[57]

Pterodroma caribbaea.wikipediaNotes: Maximum estimate; possibly extinct, but difficult to confirm due to its (former?) nocturnal nature.[3]

Capito wallacei.wikipediaNotes: Found on the summit of a single mountain in Peru.[4]

Eudyptes schlegeli.wikipediaNotes: Only mature individuals were included in the count (850 000 pairs on Macquarie & over 1000 pairs on Bishop and Clerk). Estimate is from the 1980s, but population is stable.[20]

Raphicerus sharpei.wikipediaNotes: Difficult to study due to the animal's nocturnal nature; numbers may be underestimated.[75]

Aproteles bulmerae.wikipediaNotes: Only one colony is known to exist.[6]

Diomedea epomophora.wikipediaNotes: Estimate is for mature individuals only.[38]

Apus pallidus.wikipediaNotes: Preliminary estimate extrapolated from European data.[73]

Diomedea exulans.wikipediaNotes: Estimate is for mature individuals only.[35]

Vulpes vulpes.wikipediaNotes: Estimates are uncertain because a coordinated worldwide census has never been conducted.[75]

Lontra felina.wikipediaNotes: Maximum estimate from 1991; numbers have probably fallen.[11]

Leontopithecus rosalia.wikipediaNotes: Minimum estimate; wild only.[35] In addition to these, there are about 490 golden lion tamarins in 150 zoos around the world.[36]

Eudyptes sclateri.wikipediaNotes: Population breeds in two locations: the Bounty Islands (26 000 pairs), & the Antipodes Islands (41 000 pairs).[16]

Balearica pavonina.wikipediaNotes: Divided into two subspecies: B. p. pavonina (15 000) & B. p. ceciliae (28 000 – 55 000).[70]

Arctocephalus philippii.wikipediaNotes: Estimate is from the early 1990s; numbers appear to be increasing.[37]

Puffinus bulleri.wikipediaNotes: Estimate is dated; numbers may now be lower.[91]

Hapalemur alaotrensis.wikipediaNotes: Estimates were for 2002 and showed a decline of over 50% in under ten years.[33]

Elanus scriptus.wikipediaNotes: Population subject to extreme fluctuations within this band.[44]

Canis rufus.wikipediaNotes: Maximum estimate. No more than 50 mature individuals. Previously extinct in the wild.[6]

Bos javanicus.wikipediaNotes: Maximum estimate; may be fewer than 5000. Numbers do not include the non-purebred domestic variety.[37]

Bison bonasus.wikipediaNotes: Includes 1400 semi-domestic animals and 1800 wild. Semi-domestic numbers are likely underestimated.[24]

Eudyptes chrysocome.wikipediaNotes: Only mature individuals were included in the count (1.23 million pairs); population has declined 34% in the past 37 years.[21]

Capreolus pygargus.wikipediaNotes: About 500000 were hunted annually in Russia in the 1800s.[115]

Diceros bicornis.wikipediaNotes: Four subspecies: Southern-central (2,220), South-western (1,920), Eastern (740), and Western (0; considered recently extinct).[10]

Diomedea amsterdamensis.wikipediaNotes: Only ~26 pairs breeding annually on the upper plateau of Île Amsterdam. Population was presumably higher before introduced cattle degraded lower elevation breeding sites.[9]

Thalassarche melanophrys.wikipediaNotes: Estimate is for mature individuals only.[86]

Centropus chlororhynchus.wikipediaNotes: Population is likely towards the low end of this band.[6]

Cephalorhynchus hectori Van Beneden, 188.trend: Hector's dolphin range (Maui's dolphin in green)

Gallus gallus.wikipediaNotes: Figure refers to domesticated chickens only, and is a minimum estimate. [121]

Bison bison.wikipediaNotes: Includes 500000 semi-domestic animals and 30000 wild (19000 plains bison and 11000 wood bison).[106]

Arctocephalus pusillus.wikipediaNotes: Divided into two subspecies: Cape and Australian.[72]

Grus americana.wikipediaNotes: Number refers to wild population only, of which 266 are considered self-sustaining.[13]

Charadrius obscurus.wikipediaNotes: Divided into two subspecies: C. obscurus obscurus (~1701 individuals) & C. obscurus aquilonius (~270 individuals).[36]

Antilope cervicapra.wikipediaNotes: Numbers have increased from 20000–24000 in the 1970s.[65]

Canis simensis.wikipediaNotes: One of the world's rarest canids, and Africa's most endangered carnivore.

Capra ibex.wikipediaNotes: Was as low as 100 individuals in the 1800s.[57]

Syncerus caffer.wikipediaNotes: Considered conservative. Divided into four subspecies: West African Savanna (27000), Central African Savanna (133000), Southern Savanna (670000), and Forest (60000).[113]

Tragelaphus spekii.wikipediaNotes: Yet-to-be-published research suggests the population has been overestimated.[88]

Odocoileus virginianus.wikipediaNotes: Estimated population in the United States and Canada only, with estimate of 11000000 in the US considered a minimum.[124]

Mitu mitu.wikipediaNotes: Total world population now held in two aviaries; 35% of individuals are hybrids.[3]

Coccyzus ferrugineus.wikipediaNotes: Population is likely towards the low end of this band.[3]

Diomedea antipodensis.wikipediaNotes: Estimate is for mature individuals only.[46]

Tarsius tumpara.wikipediaNotes: Amongst the world's top 25 most endangered primates.[25]
